item.title: WATO: Death blaze duo were 'good' parents
item.description: After being found guilty of manslaughter, the case of Mick and Mairead Philpott has raised questions about the role of the authorities in the family's life. An energy company has been fined a record amount for mis-selling; and are you a member of the 'precariat'?
item.itunes:subtitle: After being found guilty of manslaughter, the case of Mick and Mairead Philpott has raised questions about the role of the authorities in the family's life. An energy company has been fined a record amount for mis-selling; and are you a member of the...

item.title: WATO: Government welfare and taxation changes
item.description: We debate who wins and who loses the most in the Government's welfare and taxation changes.
item.itunes:subtitle: We debate who wins and who loses the most in the Government's welfare and taxation changes....
item.itunes:summary: We debate who wins and who loses the most in the Government's welfare and taxation changes.
item.itunes:author: BBC Radio 4

item.title: Cuts to the Legal Aid budget
item.description: On the programme today, we'll look at the impact of the £350 million cuts to the Legal Aid budget that came into force today. An Indian Court has judged that the continued production of generic cancer drugs - despite protests from the pharmaceutical company that holds the patent - is legal. So could companies be less willing to invest in research into new treatment. A year after her party entered the burmese Parliament, has Aung San Suu Kyi proved to be a hero or a disappointment? And, has the internet search engine meant that learning facts in school should be a thing of the past?

item.title: WATO: Leeds hospital stops child heart surgery
item.description: The Medical Director of the NHS has defended his intervention after Leeds General Infirmary suspended childrens' heart operations; the actor, Richard Griffiths, Harry Potter's disreputable uncle, has died; and how a row about wading birds is overshadowing Sunday's Boat Race.
